summary: This is a defense expert disclosure filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team in her criminal case (20 Cr. 330). The document outlines the expected testimony of two defense experts, Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz, who will challenge the reliability of witness memories, the concept of 'grooming,' and the validity of sexual assault allegations in the case. This document appears to be a defense filing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, likely a notice of expert witnesses. It contains a lengthy discussion of psychological factors that can lead to false allegations of sexual assault, followed by a list of defense expert witnesses and their proposed testimony areas.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for whom this expert disclosure is submitted by her counsel. The document outlines defense strategies to challenge allegations against her.

persons.name: Elizabeth Loftus
persons.context: A distinguished professor and memory expert retained by the defense. Expected to testify about the fallibility of human memory, false memories, and the effects of suggestion.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: A forensic psychiatrist retained by the defense. Expected to testify to critique the prosecution's grooming theory, hindsight bias, halo effects, and pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure for whom Maxwell allegedly recruited and groomed minors. Described as a brilliant but flawed manipulator with Cluster B personality traits.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: The prosecution's expert witness whose opinions on 'grooming' and victim vulnerabilities are directly challenged and critiqued by defense expert Dr. Park Dietz.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned as having conducted a videotaped interview with Jeffrey Epstein where Epstein discussed different kinds of power.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with political power, whom Epstein reportedly gravitated towards.

persons.name: Gerry Edelman
persons.context: Cited by Epstein in an interview as an example of a person with intellectual power.

persons.name: Natalie Bennett
persons.context: Co-author of a cited academic paper questioning the construct of grooming in child sexual abuse.

persons.name: William O'Donohue
persons.context: Co-author of multiple academic papers cited by Dr. Dietz, including on the construct of grooming and pathways to false allegations.

persons.name: Jessica Engle
persons.context: Co-author of a cited paper on pathways to false allegations of sexual assault.

persons.name: Emily R. Dworkin
persons.context: Author of meta-analysis on mental disorder risks associated with sexual assault, cited in the document.

persons.name: Anna E. Jaffe
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on a meta-analysis regarding PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Michele Bedard-Gilligan
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on a meta-analysis regarding PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Skye Fitzpatrick
persons.context: Co-author with Emily Dworkin on a meta-analysis regarding PTSD following sexual assault.

persons.name: Caron Zlotnick
persons.context: Co-author of a study on chronicity in PTSD and predictors of its course.

persons.name: Meredith Warshaw
persons.context: Co-author with Caron Zlotnick on a study on chronicity in PTSD.

persons.name: Ryan Hall
persons.context: Performed an independent medical/psychiatric evaluation of a witness (name redacted) in 2009. Will offer expert opinions and diagnoses.

persons.name: Bennett Gershman
persons.context: Distinguished Professor at Pace Law School, expert on prosecutorial misconduct. Expected to testify on best practices for prosecution integrity.

persons.name: Robert Kelso
persons.context: CEO of Forensic Pursuit. Will testify about user data, documents, photographs, and metadata from seized devices, and may rebut government expert Stephen Flatley.

persons.name: John Lopez
persons.context: Former IRS Special Agent. Will testify about his review of financial records and fund transfers provided in discovery.

persons.name: Gerald LaPorte
persons.role: Forensic Chemist/Document Dating Specialist, Defense Expert
persons.context: Director of Research Innovation at FIU's Global Forensic and Justice Center. May analyze documents for date of creation, completeness, alteration.

persons.name: Jennifer Naso
persons.context: Former US Secret Service Document Analyst. May examine documents for authorship, authentication, and potential manipulation.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney who signed and submitted the filing on behalf of the defense.

persons.name: Stephen Flatley
persons.context: Mentioned as a government expert whose testimony defense expert Robert Kelso may rebut.

connections.description: The document states the claim that Maxwell recruited and groomed minors to provide sexualized massages for Epstein, characterizing it as 'grooming-by-proxy'.
Dr. Loftus is a defense expert retained by Maxwell's counsel to provide testimony challenging witness memory in her case.
Dr. Dietz is a defense expert retained by Maxwell's counsel to provide testimony critiquing prosecution theories and evidence.
Epstein gave a videotaped interview to Steve Bannon where he discussed power and the people he gravitated towards.
Epstein cited Clinton as an example of political power in his interview, indicating a social connection or attraction to such figures.
Dr. Dietz's disclosed testimony is structured to directly critique and counter the opinions of the prosecution's expert, Dr. Rocchio.
Kelso is a defense computer forensics expert who may offer rebuttal testimony to the government's expert, Stephen Flatley.
Pagliuca is the attorney who filed this document on behalf of defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Dr. Hall is a defense expert who evaluated a witness and will offer opinions relevant to the defense of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Defense Expert Disclosure Filing
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel files a summary of expected expert testimony from Dr. Elizabeth Loftus and Dr. Park Dietz pursuant to Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 16.

events.title: Psychiatric Evaluation of Witness
events.description: Dr. Ryan Hall performed an independent medical and psychiatric evaluation of a witness (name redacted).

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 10th Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80203
University of California, Irvine School of Law
University of Virginia School of Law
keyFacts: The defense plans to call memory expert Dr. Elizabeth Loftus to testify that false memories can be created through suggestion, media coverage, and conversations, and can be described with confidence and emotion.

The defense plans to call forensic psychiatrist Dr. Park Dietz to challenge the prosecution's theory of 'grooming,' arguing it imputes motive without evidence and that 'grooming-by-proxy' has no scientific support.

Dr. Dietz will testify about cognitive biases like 'hindsight bias' (overestimating predictability after knowing an outcome) and the 'halo effect' (where positive traits influence other judgments), suggesting they may affect the case.
Dr. Dietz cites a study proposing 11 psychological pathways to false allegations of sexual assault, including lying, false memories, personality disorders, and intoxication.

The document references a videotaped interview where Jeffrey Epstein discussed being attracted to different kinds of power, citing figures like Bill Clinton (political) and Gerry Edelman (intellectual).

The defense is presenting a theory that false allegations of sexual assault can arise from various psychological conditions, including false memory, intoxication, and personality disorders like antisocial, borderline, and histrionic.

The defense has noticed several expert witnesses, including a forensic psychiatrist (Ryan Hall), a prosecutorial misconduct expert (Bennett Gershman), a computer forensics expert (Robert Kelso), a financial investigator (John Lopez), a document dating specialist (Gerald LaPorte), and a forensic document examiner (Jennifer Naso).
A key point from expert Ryan Hall's evaluation is that a witness (name redacted) did not identify Ghislaine Maxwell as a perpetrator of any abuse during the 2009 evaluation.
The document cites academic research (e.g., by Elizabeth Loftus, Emily Dworkin) to support arguments about memory reliability and the mental health impacts of assault.
The filing reserves the right to call additional experts and to rebut testimony about 'grooming' or opinions from the government's expert, Dr. Rocchio.
